channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: ISIS Fighters, Having Pledged to Fight or Die, Surrender en Masse
item.media:description: At the Kurdish screening center in Dibis, suspects are searched, their shoes taken, their pockets emptied and their belts discarded.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: More than 1,000 militants turned themselves in after the latest in a string of humiliating defeats in Iraq and Syria. Many claim to have been only cooks or clerks.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘I Am Spanish’: Thousands in Barcelona Protest a Push for Independence
item.media:description: Thousands rallied in Barcelona, Spain, on Sunday in support of a united Spanish state and against agitators for independence.
item.description: Demonstrators who oppose separation from Spain expressed solidarity with the vilified national police and waved the national flag.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Vic Journal: Catalonia’s Push for Independence Has an Unlikely Symbol: Tractors
item.media:description: In the fertile valley near Vic, Spain, farmers are working their fields but also playing a leading role in the demonstrations for independence in Catalonia.
item.description: Farmers have long played a defining role in Catalonian identity. Now they are playing a big role in the independence movement, by using their tractors.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: North Korean Leader Hails Nuclear Arsenal as ‘Powerful Deterrent’
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, the North Korean leader, and other officials at a meeting of the ruling Workers’ Party on Saturday in Pyongyang.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Kim Jong-un struck a defiant tone after President Trump said diplomacy had failed to end the crisis. And South Korean officials were worried that the North would conduct a major test Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Trailblazing Tokyo Governor, Japan Meets Its Great Disrupter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, second from right, and Yuriko Koike, center, the governor of Tokyo, were among the leaders who participated a debate in Tokyo on Saturday.
item.description: Yuriko Koike and her new party could derail Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s bid for a record-setting tenure in office, though she isn’t yet running herself.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Americans Jailed After Failed Coup in Turkey Are Hostages to Politics
item.media:description: Kubra Golge described the arrest of her husband, Serkan Golge, an American citizen and NASA scientist, as being like an amputation.
item.description: U.S. officials appear powerless to secure their release, and the dozen detainees may be bargaining chips in Turkey’s attempts to have Fethullah Gulen extradited.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Schooled in Scandal: What Makes Ukraine a Hotbed of Intrigue
item.media:description: The apartment building, right, in Poltava, Ukraine, where a man accused of leading a cybercrime ring was arrested.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Russian hacking, secret payments to Paul Manafort, suspicions of missile technology smuggled to North Korea — seemingly all illicit roads lead back to one country.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Once Shunned as ‘Drivers,’ Saudi Women Who Fought Ban Now Celebrate
item.media:description: A pair of married couples celebrating the news of Saudi women being able to drive. The husbands stood outside their cars as their wives posted selfies.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: In 1990, 47 women took to the road to demand the right to drive. They paid dearly for it, but they have lived to see the end of the ban.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Danish Police Recover Body Parts of the Journalist Kim Wall
item.media:description: Peter Madsen, right, after landing in Dragor Harbor south of Copenhagen in August. He was charged in connection with the disappearance of Kim Wall, a Swedish journalist.
item.description: The Swedish journalist’s severed head and legs were among the remains recovered. The inventor Peter Madsen has been charged in her killing.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: Suspected ISIS Members Surrender in Iraq
item.description: In the days since Iraqi forces declared victory over Islamic State fighters in Hawija, the group’s final urban stronghold in the country, more than 1,000 men have turned themselves in to the Kurdish authorities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Gas Station Explosion in Ghana Kills at Least 7 and Injures Over 100
item.media:description: Fire investigators at the site of burned cars and trucks on Sunday after the gas tanker explosion in Accra, Ghana.
item.description: The explosion in Accra, Ghana’s capital, which injured at least 132 others, sent up giant balls of fire that lit up the night sky.
item.dc:creator: TONY IYARE and MATT STEVENS

item.title: Polish Catholics Gather at Border for Vast Rosary Prayer Event
item.media:description: People walked through a forest near Poland’s border with the Czech Republic during a rosary prayer on Saturday. Some participants said they were demonstrating against the spread of Islam’s influence.
item.description: Organizers called the rosary “a mighty weapon against evil” and expected it would draw a million people. Some participants said they were demonstrating against the spread of Islam.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Mexican Radio Host’s Resignation Highlights Ties Between Government and Media
item.media:description: The radio host Leonardo Curzio during a lecture at the Universidad del Valle de México in February. Mr. Curzio quit in protest over demands to fire his colleagues.
item.description: Leonardo Curzio quit in protest over demands to fire two co-hosts, and he compared the government’s influence over the media to “a disease that kills you slowly.”
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Hosting Proms and Selling Cows: North Korean Embassies Scrounge for Cash
item.media:description: A Chinese paramilitary officer standing guard outside the North Korean embassy in Beijing.
item.description: Desperate for hard currency to keep their operations afloat, diplomats from the so-called hermit kingdom smuggle liquor, drugs, cars and guns — and engage in more mundane activities.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Russians, Heeding Navalny’s Call, Mark Putin’s Birthday With Protest
item.media:description: A crowd of mostly young people joined an antigovernment demonstration called by the jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny in Moscow on Saturday.
item.description: Youths across Russia answered a protest call from the jailed opposition leader, Aleksei Navalny, but bad weather and fear of a harsh police response limited the turnout in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Car Crashes Into Pedestrians in London
item.description: The London police detained a driver on Saturday after his car injured several pedestrians near the Natural History Museum. The crash, police said, appeared to be a “road traffic collision” and not terrorism.

item.title: Amid Catalan Crisis, Thousands Hold Rallies in Madrid and Barcelona
item.media:description: Demonstrators, mostly dressed in white, gathered in Sant Jaume square in Barcelona, Spain, on Saturday to call for Catalan and Spanish leaders to work together.
item.description: People thronged to demonstrations in the two cities as Catalan leaders appeared on the verge of announcing independence.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Tropical Storm Nate Kills 22 in Central America Amid Flooding and Landslides
item.media:description: People traveling by bus were trapped by landslides caused by Tropical Storm Nate near Casa Mata, Costa Rica.
item.description: At least 22 people were killed across Costa Rica, Honduras and Nicaragua. The storm was upgraded to a hurricane as it plowed toward the Gulf Coast.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In Long-Isolated Sudan, ‘Lot of Excitement’ as U.S. Sanctions End
item.media:description: A fruit stand in Omdurman. A host of American sanctions will be lifted permanently this coming week.
item.description: Economic sanctions imposed on Sudan had turned it into a pariah state, with a national airline reduced to one plane. Their lifting is expected to increase Western investment.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: At Least 11 Injured After Driver Crashes Car Into Pedestrians Near London History Museum
item.media:description: Ambulance workers carrying an injured woman at the scene in London on Saturday.
item.description: The driver was arrested then released, and the police said they were not treating the crash as a terrorist-related incident.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and STEPHEN FARRELL

item.title: Yemenis See Turning Point After Ousting Qaeda Militants in South
item.media:description: Yemeni soldiers after taking control of Azzan, a Qaeda stronghold, in 2014. Control of the town has seesawed back and forth between the government and the insurgents since 2011.
item.description: The seizure of a key town shows that the government is taking back the country from the extremists, Yemeni officials say.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Transgender Brazilians Embrace Hit Soap Opera: ‘Now You Can See Us’
item.media:description: Residents of a shelter for transgender and gender-nonconforming Brazilians in Rio de Janeiro watching “Edge of Desire,” a soap opera chronicling the transition of a transgender man, played by the actress Carol Duarte.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: “Edge of Desire,” watched nightly by some 50 million Brazilians, is shaping perceptions about gender identity in a nation where transgender people face stigmatization and violence.
item.dc:creator: SHANNON SIMS

item.title: In Catalonia Independence Push, Policing Becomes Politicized
item.media:description: Officers from the national riot police shot rubber bullets toward people trying to reach a polling station in Barcelona, Spain, on Oct. 1.
item.description: As the region threatens to declare independence from Spain, divisions have deepened between the national police and the regional force.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Global Economy’s Stubborn Reality: Plenty of Work, Not Enough Pay
item.media:description: A downtown area of Elyria, Ohio. As factories have closed in the city, about 30 miles from Cleveland, unemployed workers have had trouble finding jobs that pay as well as those they lost.
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.description: Even as job markets are tight in many major economies, low unemployment is failing to spur robust increases in wages, leaving workers angry.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN and JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Rebuilding After Harvey: ‘Our Son Needs Us’
item.description: Kyle Almaguer has a rare syndrome that has kept him in hospitals for most of his life. When Hurricane Harvey hit, his parents struggled to get him to safety. Now they face the daunting task of rebuilding.

item.title: A Year After a Hurricane, Stepping Out of Limbo in Haiti
item.description: The remote Haitian island of Île-à-Vache was devastated by Hurricane Matthew in October 2016. Some residents have been able to rebuild their homes. For others, it is taking longer.

item.title: Germany’s Shift to Green Power Stalls, Despite Huge Investments
item.media:description: Günter Mögele, deputy mayor and energy coordinator for Wildpoldsried, Germany, said his village has invested in an array of green-energy projects.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: The country has spent about $222 billion on renewable energy subsidies, often from higher electricity bills. But emissions are stuck at roughly 2009 levels.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: Body of Abducted Mexican Journalist Is Found
item.media:description: Journalists organized a protest in the Mexican state of San Luis Potosí on Friday after the body of a photographer, Edgar Daniel Esqueda Castro, was found on Friday.
item.description: The journalist, Edgar Daniel Esqueda Castro, a photographer for online publications, had previously reported being threatened by the police.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Mattis Discloses Part of Afghanistan Battle Plan, but It Hasn’t Yet Been Carried Out
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis testified Tuesday before a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing.
item.description: The secretary of defense revealed new, more aggressive rules of engagement, but they have yet to go into effect.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Bana al-Abed: From a Syrian War Zone to New York City
item.media:description: Bana al-Abed with her mother, Fatemah, near Bryant Park in New York on Friday.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: The young Syrian girl and her mother, Fatemah, tweeted from a war zone for months. This week, they visited New York for the publication of their new book.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Las Vegas, Harvey Weinstein, Hurricane Nate: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: After 78 Killings, a Honduran Drug Lord Partners With the U.S.
item.media:description: Hilda Caldera tending to the grave of her husband, Alfredo Landaverde, a Honduran counternarcotics adviser who was killed in 2011 by a gunman on a motorcycle.
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.description: Devis Leonel Rivera Maradiaga led a brutal drug gang that ferried tons of cocaine north. Then he approached the Drug Enforcement Administration for a deal.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Canada Letter: Thanksgiving, Old Photos and Guns
item.media:description: The first women to climb Mount Robson in British Columbia with members of their party.
item.media:credit: The New York Times/The Rudolph P. Bratty Family Collection, Ryerson Image Center
item.description: This week’s look at matters of interest to Canadians examines an exhibit of Times photos about Canada and offers some Thanksgiving recipes
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Europe Looks to Congress in Fight to Save Iran Nuclear Pact
item.media:description: The American and Iranian flags during negotiations on the Iran nuclear deal in Vienna in 2015.
item.description: With President Trump set to decertify the Iran nuclear accord, European signers of the deal hope to dissuade American lawmakers from restoring punitive sanctions.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: ‘Game Over.’ Iraqi Forces See Beginning of the End for ISIS
item.media:description: A Shiite militia fighter praying on a road outside Hawija on Friday, a day after Iraqi forces retook the city from Islamic State militants.
item.description: Celebrations break out in Hawija, where U.S.-backed forces drove ISIS from its last major urban stronghold in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Liberia Holds a Free Election. Make That ‘Free-for-All.’
item.media:description: THEY’RE FOR OPPONG Supporters of the Liberian presidential candidate George Weah, better known by his soccer name, at a campaign rally last month.
item.description: Twenty presidential candidates. Boisterous rallies. Brawls. Shifting alliances. Democracy has finally taken hold in a tiny West African country.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Fourth U.S. Soldier Is Found Dead After Ambush in Niger
item.media:description: Staff Sgt. Dustin M. Wright.
item.description: Three Special Forces soldiers were also killed and two wounded in an ambush during a routine training mission near Mali. The fourth soldier had been missing since the attack.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What’s a Science Reporter to Do When Sound Evidence Isn’t Sound?
item.media:description: A view of the United States Embassy in Havana. Some American diplomats have fallen ill in Cuba due to an alleged “sonic attack.”
item.description: I knew this article — about the alleged “sonic attack” at the U.S. Embassy in Cuba — would be very different than the ones I usually write. There was not even an official medical report.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Tom Alter, Blue-Eyed Star of Bollywood Films, Dies at 67
item.media:description: Tom Alter in 1989. An incongruous figure in Bollywood who spoke Hindi and Urdu fluently.
item.description: Born to missionaries in India, Mr. Alter went on to act in more than 300 films, often as Western diplomats, colonials, priests and police officers.
item.dc:creator: AMISHA PADNANI

item.title: Theresa May’s Nightmare Week Ends With Party Coup Attempt
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain had intended to use a speech on Wednesday to relaunch her leadership. Instead, it was a disaster that has made her survival in office the subject of frantic speculation.
item.description: Just as Brexit talks were supposed to get serious, the Conservatives have imploded. The British prime minister is dangling, with no obvious successor.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Canada to Pay Millions in Indigenous Lawsuit Over Forced Adoptions
item.media:description: Marcia Brown Martel, the lead plaintiff in the “Sixties Scoop” class action lawsuit, was repeatedly taken away from her reserve, perhaps 10 times, until 1972, when she was adopted by a non-indigeneous family in Southern Ontario.
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.description: A 1960s government program took indigenous children from their families and put them up for adoption by nonnative parents.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Brought Together by Pain, 3 Girls Forced Into Marriage Have New Dreams
item.media:description: Gul Meena showed the scars on her face. After she ran away from an arranged marriage, her brother and uncle found her and attacked her with an ax.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: One survived an ax attack; another, acid; a third, torture. But in an Afghan women’s shelter they helped one another, and now their lives are changing.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: A Child Bride Leaves Fear Behind
item.description: Gul Meena is starting a new life in Sweden after spending five years in a women's shelter in Afghanistan. The 18-year-old was attacked by her family with an ax after leaving her abusive husband.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Berlin’s ‘Newspaper Poet’ Walks in a Long Line of Eccentrics
item.media:description: Holger Bleck, who sells newspapers by composing and reciting rhyming versions of the news, at the Ständige Vertretung bar in Berlin.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For 20 years, Holger Bleck has made poems from the day’s news to sell papers, becoming a cult figure in the bars and restaurants of the German capital.
item.dc:creator: SALLY McGRANE

item.title: IHT Retrospective Blog: 1967: Wilson Receives Approval From Party on Bid to ECC
item.description: At the Labor Party conference there was a vote on government policy to join the Common Market.
item.dc:creator: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: France Has ‘Champagne,’ Portugal Has ‘Port.’ Should Australia Have ‘Uggs?’
item.media:description: Eddie Oygur is a shoemaker in Lidcombe, Australia. His company, Australian Leather, is being sued over sales of Ugg-like footwear in the United States.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: A legal fight over the boots irritates Australians, including the prime minister, who say too many of their famous names are taken by others.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: ‘I Thought That Barcelona Was Spanish’: Tourists Caught in Catalonia Unrest
item.media:description: Tourists passed pro-independence flags in Barcelona, Spain, days before the Catalan independence referendum. The vote and the related protests have caught many visitors by surprise.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Visitors expressed surprise, excitement and, in some cases, admiration after being present during the independence protests.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Catalonia Government Declares Overwhelming Vote for Independence
item.media:description: Josep Lluís Trapero, center, Catalonia’s police chief, arriving at a Madrid courthouse on Friday.
item.description: The official result sets up a potential showdown with Madrid, as separatists had pledged to make the result binding within 48 hours and unilaterally declare independence.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
